data.text: Contents
Introduction

This guidance was written to ensure a system is in place for identifying individual radiology procedures where there is a possibility that the x-ray exposure to the skin of the patient could result in tissue effects such as erythema. This procedure provides guidance dose levels and recommends actions to be taken
To ensure a skin dose estimate is obtained, where necessary, in order that further follow up can be considered
This follows the IRMER17 regulations requirement to keep exposures As Low As Reasonably Practicable.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to provide guidance on action to follow if a patient's skin receives x-ray exposure that may result in tissue effects.
Definitions

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Local Radiology Governance Groups Duties Are:

Local Radiology Governance Groups – Are responsible for the local level implementation, adherence and monitoring of this Guidance as well as it's communication to wider stakeholders where required. These groups are also responsible for ensuring that any amendments required are communicated to the author in a timely manner for document revision.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
Managers of Radiology services – must ensure that this guidance is made available and communicated to their teams and that their teams have
adequate training in these matters.
Radiology Operators and Practitioners, Radiographers, Radiology Nurses and radiology assistants involved in screening using x-rays – should follow the guidance outlined in section 5 below.
Diagnostic Medical Physics experts to provide advice and assist with a skin dose calculation if required. mse.radiation.protection@nhs.net
Radiology skin dose follow up guidance

Most modern x-ray equipment provides a real time view of Dose Area Product (DAP) and Air KERMA (AK) as well as visible and audible indication of screening time. The most appropriate method to establish the probability of tissue effects is by the use of the Air KERMA display on the machine. Reference AK is calculated at a specific point 15 cm in the direction of the tube from the mechanical iso-centre of the  machine.  This  value,  when  corrected  for  backscatter  within  the  patient, represents the maximum possible entrance dose
If this displayed value is less than 2 Gray (Gy), no further action is necessary. (A DAP value of 300,000 mGy.cm is a suitable alternative action level)

If this displayed AK value is between  and  Gy, then information should be provided for the patient about the possible effect of transient erythema. This may be verbally or in the form of a pamphlet. The patient will be instructed to seek medical advice if they experience any effects

If the displayed AK value is over 5 Gy, there is a high likelihood of a transient effect but  also  the  possibility  of  permanent  damage  to  the  skin.  At  this  point  it  is recommended that a skin dose estimate be performed. This uses the DAP value and information on x-ray projections and patient positioning to establish a more accurate value to guide decision making, between recommending self-examination and arranging follow up via the patient's GP or hospital outpatients skin clinic.

Skin dose information
To obtain a skin dose estimate the following information is required:
Hospital, room and unit used
Date of procedure and any other recent fluoroscopy procedures the patient has had
Examination Protocols used (Exactly what was being done)
Total Air KERMA (Gy) and DAP Reading (mGy.cm2)
Primary Orientation of the  x-ray equipment and percentage of the DAP that it contributes to
Estimate of source to skin distance SSD (cm)
Source to detector distance SID (cm)
Anatomical Landmark for image and size of area irradiated (Field size) (cm)
If several different projections overlapped with the principal field please provide field information, as above (where the equipment allows), for each
Once this information is collated, e-mail a copy to the Radiology Physics Team at Southend Hospital, the appropriate Radiation Protection Supervisor (RPS) and the Radiology Governance Lead.
The following team email can be used: mse.radiation.protection@nhs.net
In cases where a skin dose calculation is necessary, a Datix incident should also be submitted because of the likelihood of further action.
Duty of candour to the patient

After a discussion with the radiologist, ideally at the time of the procedure, the possibility of a skin reaction should be explained to the patient. It is important to emphasise that the importance of the x-ray procedure despite possible risks the high dose may cause. The discussion may also include the range of possible reactions from a mild reddening in the first month through to ulceration a year or so later. The patient should be advised which area(s) may be affected by explaining the entrance points of the x-rays

The patient should be given an appropriate number to contact should they have any other questions prior to being contacted once the skin estimate has been produced. This should be documented on the RIS and the completed Datix form

All patients requiring a skin dose estimate should also be informed of the high dose effects of radiation and supplied with the patient information pamphlet. Where the patient is unconscious the ward staff looking after the patient should be given the radiation pamphlet in order that this can be passed onto the patient on discharge. This should be clearly documented in the patient's notes at the time of the radiology procedure.

The ward should be made aware of the aftercare required and informed of the symptoms that should be looked out for. Once the patient is conscious, duty of candour should be carried out by the radiology department.
Patient consent is obtained prior to the procedure occurring where potential risks should be explained to the patient.

Post skin dose estimate completion
The relevant RPS should save the skin dose estimate on the RIS, the radiology drive and the Datix system for future access
The relevant RPS should consult with the interventional radiologist and the referring physician regarding any recommended follow up from the case

It is this RPS's responsibility to ensure the initial duty of candour has taken place, including ensuring a follow up has occurred with patients whom it was not possible to communicate the information with at the time of the procedure.

The patient should be contacted by the Datix investigating officer and informed of the recommendations and relevant clinical appointments made. It is recommended that patients with a risk of developing deterministic effects are followed up by the referring physician at 3 monthly intervals for a period of one year.
Training requirements

No specific training requirements, other than knowledge and understanding of this guidance. Staff should have an understanding of the risks of radiation exposure to skin and be able to explain this to patients if required.
